cons: Supportive nature and polite as well

pros: will learn a lot of lessons in a bad way
cons: lack of management, min pay with the max workload

pros: it is a dynamic place to work with the opportunity to learn and improve on the job. other staff are always ready to assist
cons: there are no cons for now

pros:
-Decent pay. Good benefits plan.

-Slow days (IFR conditions) give you freedom to relax and do whatever you want. 

And you need slow days like this; if you get a few busy days in a row (3 or more) you will contemplate just quitting right there and going home, I know I did at points. Hopefully weather is bad enough in a given week that you get a break every once and a while, if not you'd might as well start writing your suicide note.
cons:
-When it's busy IT'S BUSY. This was the most stressed I've been at any job I've ever had, and I was here for 2 years.

-The amount of aircraft and flights scheduled/congested (the reason the job is so stressful and busy) is a direct result of greed. If we had 12 aircraft available they would make the schedule using 14 aircraft simultaneously, completely assuming we would receive more from maintenance. What usually happened is planes would go down instead, and we'd have less than 12 by the afternoon. I've had to YELL at people who would argue with me after I cancelled their flight after I have no other choice, because management made everything so terrible. Literally had no aircraft they could use. I don't want to yell at ANYONE, that's not me as a person. More flights = more money, so let's pack this school with kids from China and grovel to the CCP for cash.

-Look at the job descriptions for Dispatcher, it's hilarious. They literally list EVERYTHING there is to do at the college "plus other duties as required". Instructors fall into this boat as well, they do ramp/scheduling as well because this place is so disorganized. Dispatchers have to learn and do almost everything in flight operations, things you would never even think about doing. And there's only 2 of you dealing with 50+ students/instructors at once, definitely not enough attention given to individuals.

-Management are just not good people, they heavily distance themselves from the actual operations of this school, as if the whole thing is too much of a bother to deal with. Don't want to elaborate too much further but I'll be brief. They are in a completely separate building from the actual Flight Operations/Aircraft Maintenance shop, and for some reason they see themselves as superior to the actual heart of this school, which is obviously FLIGHT Operations. Oh and I'm sure they get paid handfuls more than any of the operation staff.

You'll mostly see them wandering around the college not really doing anything, attending the odd meeting here and there where they just sit around and eat Swiss Chalet every week (good spending of the budget, guys). Or bossing people around and pretending to know how anything works from an operational standpoint. I've had somebody from management team come up to me and tell me he wanted to physically fight somebody else on my Operations team because he "didn't show him proper respect"? Literally the management guy and the guy he was wanting to fight were equals in title this was extremely unprofessional; A good summary for this whole school.

Wouldn't come back to working here if they begged me.
Not very much money for lots of work

pros:
-lots of flying available 
-large fleet of aircraft
cons:
-toxic management
-not paid for time spent on the ground waiting for students

pros: Lots of flight hours, about 600 per year working with the China program
cons: Not paid of pre and post flight briefings, asked to do other work like in class groundschools. Long hours.

pros: Work as much or as little as you like. RRSP contributions, health benefits.
a very good job for most of people
cons: a little bit too much work

review_title: Great school for Students/ Training. Working not so much
pros: Quick to build flying Hr's and gain some experience in flying smaller planes.
cons: Some of the equipment is not up to standards. Some of the aircraft are old and not kept up well. Lack of planes on many days. This creates alot of days where your not getting as many hours as you would like. Paid by the Hour. You may be there for eight hours but you only fly for four. This in turn means you only get paid for the four hours you were in the air... The building could use some updates as well.

I've both attended and worked for the moncton flight college. 

Most days are filled with delays. The pay is far below Industry standard, you are not compensated remotely enough for your time. Not compensated for cancellations due to bad weather, overbooking,  maintenance.

There's no base pay starting out, if you can't fly you don't make money. This happens more frequently than you may expect. The base pay once you've upgraded isn't much either.

pros: dont have to come to work when weather is not good
cons: pay is below the standart instructor pay. they promise 25 hourly, pay 20 cause they exclude preflight and postflight working hours which has to be done by instructor

pros: Lots of work and experience to be gained.
cons: Not overly generous on the paycheck. You won't go hungry working here, but you won't be driving a Ferrari either.

pros: Excellent maintenance. Constant flow of students.
cons: Management is very disorganized and are bad at communication. Instructors get a very low hourly pay rate despite how much their worked. You are expected (but not forced) to work at least 11-12 hour days.
